MajorClaims.MC1: both alternative sources and traditional teaching methods from educators are equally important in children's acquisition of knowledge
MajorClaims.MC2: alternative sources information and traditional education systems are equally important in children's development

Claims.C1: learners can obtain more useful knowledge from teachers than from other sources
Claims.C2: technologies are vital in students' learning
Claims.C3: formal education approaches are also indispensable

Premises.P1: the widespread of alternative sources of knowledge has played an important role in students' acquisition of knowledge
Premises.P2: Computers can be programmed to provide an endless numbers of questions in diverse range of fields, and as the students answer these questions, the facts has been learned and reinforced
Premises.P3: A case in point is the reading and listening parts of TOEFL iBT exams, as candidates have to answer many questions in a limited period of time
Premises.P4: when students have some academic problems, they can post those to some websites and receive correct answers from unknown people in faraway places without any costs
Premises.P5: in the past, conducting a research require long hours of searching in library shelves, now all can be done at a click of a button
Premises.P6: schools and university are places in which students gather to be educated and learn from each others as well as formal educators
Premises.P7: At schools, students' development has been orchestrated stage by stage, step by step by experienced teachers, and their acquisition of knowledge is guided and backed up in a systematic way
